arm_group.description:
Three sessions per week:
Supervised exercise program

brief_summary.textblock:
To assess the effectiveness of an exercise program developed during pregnancy (land/aquatic
      activities) aerobic and muscular tonification, on control to the prevention to Gestational
      Diabetes. And to assess if excessive maternal weight gain is an influence in the diagnostic.

detailed_description.textblock:
A clinical, randomized controlled trial was used. 342 pregnant women without obstetric
      contraindications accepted informed consent for inclusion in the study. Finally, 257 were
      studied, 101 in intervention group (IG, n= 101) and 156 in control group (GC, n= 156). A
      physical exercise program three times per week during pregnancy was developed. The duration
      of session was 60 minutes and 50 minutes in land and water, respectively.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Healthy pregnant women

          -  At week 8-14

          -  Adherence 80% (minimum) until the end of pregnancy

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Contraindications appointed by American College of Obstetricians & Gynecologists
             (ACOG)

          -  No adherence

intervention.description: Combined two land aerobic sessions and one aquatic activities session

clinical_study.official_title: Gestational Diabetes. The Rol of Exercise in the Prevention

other_outcome.description: macrosomia, type of delivery, birth weight

oversight_info.authority: Spain: Comité Ético de Investigación Clínica

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Gestational Diabetes. The Role of Exercise in the Prevention

secondary_outcome.description: Maternal weight gain above guidelines recommendations by Institute of Medicine and National Research Council (IOM)

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Prevention
